title: Efficient coding with chaotic neural networks: A journey from neuroscience to physics and back
abstract: arXiv:2408.01949v1 Announce Type: cross  Abstract: This essay, derived from a lecture at "The Physics Modeling of Thought" workshop in Berlin in winter 2023, explores the mutually beneficial relationship between theoretical neuroscience and statistical physics through the lens of efficient coding and computation in cortical circuits. It highlights how the study of neural networks has enhanced our understanding of complex, nonequilibrium, and disordered systems, while also demonstrating how neuroscientific challenges have spurred novel developments in physics. tldr: The paper focuses on the efficient coding and computation in cortical circuits, connecting theoretical neuroscience with statistical physics. It discusses the mutual benefits of studying neural networks for understanding complex systems, nonequilibrium dynamics, and disordered systems in physics, and vice versa. The discussed work starts from the chaos in random neural networks and progresses to the efficient coding and the partial suppression of chaotic fluctuations. Key concepts from statistical physics, including phase transitions and critical phenomena, are highlighted for explaining the computational capabilities of neural networks.
